name: Values and Public Life
description: Students attaining the certificate will be equipped to bring informed discussion of values into the public sphere and to integrate a critical value perspective into their future studies and pursuits. The program is open to undergraduates in all disciplines, and students are invited to apply at the end of the sophomore year.

req_list.name: Introduction Course
req_list.explanation: Students must take PHI / CHV 202 as an introduction course.

req_list.name: Core Course
req_list.explanation: Students must take one course out of the following core requirements.

req_list.name: Seminar Course
req_list.explanation: Students must take a Junior/Senior Seminar in Values and Public Life (topics change from year to year) or, in an exceptional scenario (e.g., study abroad), another seminar on normative issues approved by the program director.

req_list.name: Thematic Courses
req_list.explanation: Students must identify an area of focus and take 2 courses with an explicit values component related to it, chosen by the student in consultation with the program director.  Some illustrative focus areas (or “themes”) are: Bioethics, Cognitive psychology, ethics, and public policy; Democracy in theory and practice; Global justice and human right;  Constitutionalism and the rule of law; History of thought about political justice, human rights, or some other core concept in public morality; Public dilemmas in literature; Ethics, religion, and theology
